prompt: <description>Part 1: Three-Dimensional Rectangular Prism with a Tapered Top and Bottom Begin by creating a new coordinate system at the origin with no rotation and zero translation. This will be the basis for constructing the 2D sketch of the first part. Sketch First, create a rectangle with the following line segments: 1. Line 1: Start Point [0, 0]; End Point [0.15, 0] 2. Line 2: Start Point [0.15, 0]; End Point [0.15, 0.1] 3. Line 3: Start Point [0.15, 0.1]; End Point [0.65, 0.1] 4. Line 4: Start Point [0.65, 0.1]; End Point [0.65, 0] 5. Line 5: Start Point [0.65, 0]; End Point [0.75, 0] 6. Line 6: Start Point [0.75, 0]; End Point [0.75, 0.65] 7. Line 7: Start Point [0.75, 0.65]; End Point [0.0, 0.65] 8. Line 8: Start Point [0.0, 0.65]; End Point [0.0, 0.0] This will create a closed sketch of a rectangle with a tapered top and bottom, considering the Start Point and End Point as the vertices of the shapes. Extrusion and Scaling Next, scale the 2D sketch by 0.75 for both the X and Y dimensions using the 'sketch_scale' parameter. After scaling, define the extrusion depth for the 3D model as follows: 1. Depth towards normal: 0.45 units 2. Depth opposite normal: 0 units These operations will result in the creation of a new solid body representing the first part, which is a three-dimensional rectangular prism with a slightly tapered top and bottom. Dimensions The final dimensions of the prism are: 1. Length: 0.75 units 2. Width: 0.75 units 3. Height: 0.45 units With these instructions, the junior CAD designer should be able to generate the parametric CAD model of the first part. Continue with the next parts in the same manner using the provided information if necessary.</description>
